story.text: We explore data represented in the simple but still quite general JSON format. We count the number of scalar elements, NUMBER, STRING, TRUE, FALSE and NULL and report this in a form that mimics in structure the ARRAY and OBJECT elements encountered.
Distributions aid spotting missing data or unexpected elements when translating data formats.
We found a similar analysis useful when inspecting and translating material life cycle data in 2012 as mentioned on slide 13 of our report. [http://c2.com/~ward/svg/formula-chart.pdf pdf]
We choose for our first test case the moderately complicated [[Source Code Control]] data generated and uploaded as if real data.  [http:/plugin/json/source-code-control json]
From our first handmade sketches we begin developing a plugin to render the shape and size of any dataset.

From counts we can observe that three programs omit the committers field, 141-138=3, the description field is sometimes null but never omitted, 130+11=141, and the average number of committers per program approaches three, 390รท141=2.766
A possible representation as json array triples containing type, count, and members of the distribution. We materialize fields to fit this structure.
The essential transformation here has been to replace elements of an ARRAY or field values of an OBJECT with a collection of members representing counts of values distinguished by kind.
Kind of scalar types will be their type names.
Kind of ARRAY will be derived from kind of elements.
Kind of OBJECT will be derived from keys combinations.
We're developing a plugin to support this analysis and as a guide for subsequent data transformation.
See [[About Tally Plugin]] for github links.

item.text: We explore data represented in the simple but still quite general JSON format. We count the number of scalar elements, NUMBER, STRING, TRUE, FALSE and NULL and report this in a form that mimics in structure the ARRAY and OBJECT elements encountered.
We found a similar analysis useful when translating environmental data in 2012.
We found a similar analysis useful when translating environmental data in 2012 as mentioned on slide 13 of our report. [http://c2.com/~ward/svg/formula-chart.pdf pdf]
We choose for our first test case the moderately complicated data representing [[Source Code Control]] [http:/plugin/json/source-code-control json]
We choose for our first test case the moderately complicated [[Source Code Control]] data generated and uploaded as if real data.  [http:/plugin/json/source-code-control json]
A handmade sketch of the desired output.
A possible representation, itself in json.

ARRAY
  OBJECT*50
    project: STRING*22
    manager: STRING*22
    programs: OBJECT*141
      name: STRING*141
      description: STRING*130 NULL*11
      committers: ARRAY*141
        STRING*390
A possible representation, itself in json tripples.
A possible representation, itself in json triples, type, count, and members.
A possible representation as json array triples containing type, count, and members of the distribution.
The essential transformation here has been to replace elements of an ARRAY or field values of an OBJECT with a collection of members representing counts of values distinguished by kind.
Kind of scalar types will be their type names.
Kind of ARRAY will be derived from kind of their elements.
Kind of ARRAY will be derived from kind of elements.
Kind of OBJECT will be derived from keys combinations.
We found a similar analysis useful when translating material life cycle data in 2012 as mentioned on slide 13 of our report. [http://c2.com/~ward/svg/formula-chart.pdf pdf]
